Definition 2.2.

Consider particle y, unforced particle w, and force fâ†’y applied to particle y. Cy1 and Cy2 are two different paths with the same beginning and end positions.

Definition 2.3.

The total energy of particle y relative to point w with respect to â„±a is

Eyâ¢w/a=Tyâ¢w/a+Vyâ¢w.

The total energy of particle y relative to an unforced particle w with respect to an inertial reference frame â„±a is conserved if the forces acting on particle y are conserved. That is,

Eyâ¢w/aâ¢(t1)=Eyâ¢w/aâ¢(t2),

or equivalently EË™yâ¢w/a=0. This is known as conservation of energy.

2.2 Potential Energy

We have discussed four different types of forces:

  1. 1.

    linear spring force (conservative)

  2. 2.

    linear viscous force (non-conservative)

  3. 3.

    gravitational force (conservative)

  4. 4.

    reaction force (not applicable)

Since linear spring forces and gravitational forces are conservative, we can write out a potential function for each.

2.2.1 Potential Energy of a Linear Spring

Consider particles y and w with a spring connected between them, where d is the unstretched length of the spring, â„“ is the stretched length of the spring, and xs=â„“âˆ’d is the extension of the spring.

fâ†’y=âˆ’kâ¢xsâ¢râ†’yâ¢wâ€–râ†’yâ¢wâ€–2,

An infinitesimally small change in the length of the spring is given by

dâ¢râ†’yâ¢w=ğ“•â†’bğ–³â¢[âˆ’dâ¢â„“00]=âˆ’dâ¢â„“â¢bâ†’1.

We know that â„“=xs+d, so dâ¢â„“=dâ¢xs+dâ¢(d). Since the unstretched length d is constant, dâ¢(d)=0 and dâ¢â„“=dâ¢xs. Therefore,

dâ¢râ†’yâ¢w=âˆ’dâ¢xsâ¢bâ†’1.

Substituting this result into the definition of work and integrating gives

Wyâ¢wâ¢(fâ†’y) =âˆ«râ†’yâ¢wâ¢(t1)râ†’yâ¢wâ¢(t2)fâ†’yâ‹…drâ†’yâ¢w

=âˆ’kâ¢âˆ«xsâ¢(t1)xsâ¢(t2)xsâ¢(bâ†’1â‹…bâ†’1)1â¢dxs

Wyâ¢wâ¢(fâ†’y)=âˆ«râ†’yâ¢wâ¢(t1)râ†’yâ¢wâ¢(t2)fâ†’yâ‹…drâ†’yâ¢w=âˆ«râ†’yâ¢wâ¢(t1)râ†’yâ¢wâ¢(t2)(myâ¢gâ†’)â‹…drâ†’yâ¢w.

Example 2.1.

Consider particle y with mass m released from rest on a frictionless slide at a height h.

Gravity is acting in the downwards direction. What is the magnitude of the velocity of particle y relative to point w with respect to frame â„±a when particle y reaches the bottom of the slide?

Solution. Since there is no friction acting on the particle and gravity is a conservative force, the total energy of the particle is conserved throughout its motion. The kinetic and potential energies are to be computed using

Tyâ¢w/a=12â¢mâ¢vâ†’yâ¢w/aâ‹…vâ†’yâ¢w/a=12â¢mâ¢â€–vâ†’yâ¢w/aâ€–22,
Vyâ¢w=âˆ’mâ¢gâ†’â‹…râ†’yâ¢w.

To solve for the relevant positions and velocities, we follow the 5 steps to success in kinematics, resulting in

râ†’yâ¢w=ğ“•â†’ağ–³â¢[xaya0]

and

vâ†’yâ¢w/a=râ†’yâ¢wâˆ™a=ğ“•â†’ağ–³â¢[xË™ayË™a0].

The potential energy of the particle is then computed as

Vyâ¢w =âˆ’mâ¢gâ†’â‹…râ†’yâ¢w
=âˆ’mâ¢[0âˆ’g0]â¢[xaya0]
=mâ¢gâ¢ya.

The total energy of the particle is thus

Eyâ¢w/a =Tyâ¢w/a+Vyâ¢w
=12â¢mâ¢â€–vâ†’yâ¢w/aâ€–22+mâ¢gâ¢ya.

Since the total energy of the particle is to be conserved, we can equate the total energy at the initial release of the particle (t1) to the total energy when it reaches the bottom of the slide (t2). At t1, we know that â€–vâ†’yâ¢w/aâ¢(t1)â€–2=0 and yaâ¢(t1)=h. At t2, we know that yaâ¢(t2)=0 and â€–vâ†’yâ¢w/aâ¢(t1)â€–2 is unknown. These values are substituted into the conservation of energy expression to yield

Eyâ¢w/aâ¢(t1) =Eyâ¢w/aâ¢(t2)
12â¢mâ¢â€–vâ†’yâ¢w/aâ¢(t1)â€–22+mâ¢gâ¢yaâ¢(t1) =12â¢mâ¢â€–vâ†’yâ¢w/aâ¢(t2)â€–22+mâ¢gâ¢yaâ¢(t2)
mâ¢gâ¢h =12â¢mâ¢â€–vâ†’yâ¢w/aâ¢(t2)â€–22
gâ¢h =12â¢â€–vâ†’yâ¢w/aâ¢(t2)â€–22,

which is rearranged to obtain

â€–vâ†’yâ¢w/aâ¢(t2)â€–2=2â¢gâ¢h.

Notice that we did not need to consider reaction forces to get this answer, as they do not contribute to the work done on the particle between t1 and t2. However, it is important to note that we did not obtain the equations of motion that govern the behavior of the particle. Instead, we only obtained the velocity of the particle at a particular instance in time.
